Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Inlet Perturbations on Superstructures of Turbulent Boundary Layers- Toward Global Flow Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is about the investigation of a very fundamental issue in turbulent flows, the issue of the effects of small flow changes close to a solid wall on the development of very long eddies farther downstream. The practical outcome of such understanding would be the possibility to control turbulence downstream by small modifications of the flow upstream, leading to improvements in industrial applications, such as film cooling technology, commercial and military flight, design of wind energy turbine blades and saving energy in cases where fluid pumped over a solid surface is turbulent.

Although turbulent boundary layers have been studied for over 50 years, the understanding of them remains the cause of ontroversy in the turbulence community. Such understanding is critical, however, if we are to develop practical control schemes that can help mitigate the energy penalty of turbulent boundary layers. Recent studies have shown that there are Large Scale Motions (LSMs) and Very Large Scale Motions (VLSMs) that carry more than 50% of the Reynolds stresses and kinetic energy. The largest of these motions have scales of the order of O(1δ) ≤ L ≤ O(10δ) and are often also referred to as superstructures. The hypothesis in the proposed study is to demonstrate the possibility to achieve Global Flow Control of the downstream flow by manipulating the inlet conditions in such a way to control the "superstructures". Our team from the USA and Australia seeks to explain the mechanisms by which such complex interactions are possible, and also to explore how these superstructures can modulate the inner region and vice versa. The proposed research consists of high Reynolds number wind tunnel experiments and high fidelity Direct Numerical Simulations (DNS) to study spatially-developing turbulent boundary layers under the influence of different inlet perturbations (e.g., including steady and unsteady). The low Reynolds number simulations will uncover the impact of inlet perturbations on superstructures and will provide optimum configurations to consider in the moderate and high Reynolds number studies. Recruitment of students and outreach will be facilitated by synergies with the ongoing Summer Research Institute established by the PI in 2013. In addition, there will be links to Puerto Rico institutions, where the co-PIs have a strong track record of student recruitment. The PIs also have a plan bringing K-12 teachers to Workshop on Wind Energy Turbulence each summer for the duration of the grant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the present study, we have evaluated the physical mechanisms behind turbulent boundary layers subject to inlet perturbations. The main idea was to assess the role of localized blowing-suction flow perturbations on large and very-large scale motions (i.e., LSMs  and VLSMs) and to determine the feasibility of using the properties of large-scale motions for global flow control. Since the large turbulent structures in the flow contain the most energy, significant changes on the flow can be achieved by manipulating them, with possibly minimal energy input. Incompressible jets transversely issuing into a spatially-developing turbulent boundary layer is one of the most challenging types of three dimensional flows due to its thermal-fluid complexity and technological applications; for instance, film cooling of turbine blades, fuel or dilution air injection in gas turbine engines, thrust vector control, chimney plumes, just to name a few.

Intellectual Merit: We have performed high spatial/temporal resolution Direct Numerical Simulation (DNS) of turbulent boundary layers subject to crossflow blowing jets. Major research outcomes are as follows: (i) localized blowing provoked an evident energy redistribution among two specific spanwise wavelengths in the buffer region according to the co-spectra of thermal and spanwise vorticity fluctuations, (ii) the presence of a strong Favorable Pressure Gradient induced a significant damping effect on the wake development of the most energetic turbulent structure (i.e., the counter-rotating vortex pair) while turbulent structures showed an oblong or elongated shape with a spanwise squeezed silhouette, (iii) it was not observed an increase of the Stanton number across the jet hole as occurred in the skin friction coefficient, revealing a breakdown of the Reynolds analogy, (iv) small wall blowing perturbations in a turbulent channel proliferate the number of vortical motions in the outer layer of the channel, (v) Reynolds stresses are increased significantly in the log-layer of the channel and these changes of Reynolds normal stresses are largely brought about by large-scale motions, and (vi) more than 85% of Reynolds shear stresses are contributed by large-scale motions of the flow.  

Broader Impacts: The investigation performed under this grant has enriched the understanding of the dynamics of turbulent coherent structures subject to surface flow perturbation. Additionally, the influence of bio-inspired surfaces on drag reduction in wall-bounded flows has also been investigated. The obtained information and extensive DNS database will permit the advancement of innovative Large Eddy Simulation (LES) models, particularly for passive scalar fluxes, which has not been addressed as of today by the research community. Moreover, the acquired knowledge may lead to the design of smart flow/scalar-flux control tools to achieve drag reduction and/or heat transfer enhancement. 

Furthermore, this grant has also promoted the education and training of several graduate and undergraduate students. Particularly at the University of Puerto Rico-Mayaguez (a minority serving institution), the present project has provided research skill development to five students from the underrepresented Hispanic community in the following areas: fluid dynamics, turbulence, coherent structures, high performance computing, visualization techniques, parallel programming and high-order statistics.
